title: JavaScript Fundamentals Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of JavaScript basics
subject: programming

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct way to declare a variable in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, variables are declared using 'var', 'let', or 'const' keywords. The 'var' keyword is the traditional way to declare variables.

questions.question: What will be the output of: console.log(typeof null);
questions.explanation: This is a well-known quirk in JavaScript. typeof null returns 'object', which is considered a bug in the language but is maintained for compatibility.

questions.question: JavaScript is a case-sensitive language.
questions.explanation: Yes, JavaScript is case-sensitive. Variables 'myVariable' and 'myvariable' would be treated as different variables.

questions.question: Which method is used to add an element to the end of an array?
questions.explanation: The push() method adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length of the array.

questions.question: What keyword is used to create a function in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The 'function' keyword is used to declare functions in JavaScript, though arrow functions (=>) are also available in ES6+.

questions.question: What does the '===' operator do in JavaScript?
options: Compares values and types without coercion
questions.explanation: The '===' operator performs strict equality comparison, checking both value and type without any type coercion.

questions.question: Arrays in JavaScript can contain elements of different data types.
questions.explanation: Yes, JavaScript arrays are heterogeneous, meaning they can contain elements of different data types in the same array.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a primitive data type in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Array is not a primitive data type in JavaScript. It's actually an object type. The primitive types are: string, number, boolean, undefined, null, symbol, and bigint.
